Graphical abstract Alkali metal batteries are regarded as prominent contender to fulfil demand of electric vehicles and electronic devices. Toward broader implementation, the obstacle lies in intricate multi-electron and multi-step redox reaction associated with sluggish conversion kinetics. Catalysts are introduced to modulate conversion barrier and thus accelerate reaction kinetics. Here, we make a comprehensive review on key progress in catalyst design with emphasis toward their catalytic mechanism. Then, the rational design and innovative direction are provided for future catalyst in metal-sulfur/gas battery and beyond. Lithium metal batteries are regarded as prominent contenders to address the pressing needs owing to the high theoretical capacity. Toward the broader implementation, the primary obstacle lies in the intricate multi-electron, multi-step redox reaction associated with sluggish conversion kinetics, subsequently giving rise to a cascade of parasitic issues. In order to smooth reaction kinetics, catalysts are widely introduced to accelerate reaction rate via modulating the energy barrier. Over past decades, a large amount of research has been devoted to the catalyst design and catalytic mechanism exploration, and thus the great progress in electrochemical performance has been realized. Therefore, it is necessary to make a comprehensive review toward key progress in catalyst design and future development pathway. In this review, the basic mechanism of lithium metal batteries is provided along with corresponding advantages and existing challenges detailly described. The main catalysts employed to accelerate cathode reaction with emphasis on their catalytic mechanism are summarized as well. Finally, the rational design and innovative direction toward efficient catalysts are suggested for future application in metal-sulfur/gas battery and beyond. This review is expected to drive and benefit future research on rational catalyst design with multi-parameter synergistic impacts on the activity and stability of next-generation metal battery, thus opening new avenue for sustainable solution to climate change, energy and environmental issues, and the potential industrial economy. Keywords Energy storage and conversion Metal battery Sulfur battery Air battery Catalytic effect Heterogeneous catalyst Homogeneous catalyst 1 Introduction Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), recognized as the energy storage benchmark, have been successfully applied in a veriaty of portable electronic devices and electricity system [1]. Nevertheless, the rapid expansion of electric vehicles and the implementation of large-scale smart grids necessitate batteries with high energy density, which renders LIBs less competitive for the future, due to their constrained theoretical cpacity [2–4] (Fig. 1 ). Traditional LIBs operate based on the Li-ion intercalation mechanism, in conjunction with cathode materials like LiFePO4 and LiMn2O4 [5]. Restricted by the cathode, low energy density of 350–400 W h kg−1 can be realized, which greatly hinders their prospective application [6]. By contrast, rechargeable batteries based on conversion reaction, such as lithium metal batteries (e.g., lithium sulfur/gas batteries), exhibit notable enhancement in discharging-charging capacity [7–11]. In typical Li-S battery, sulfur cathode engages in a sequential conversion reaction with lithium anode, while being separated by an ion-conducting liquid or solid electrolyte. Normally, the overall reaction can be represented by the following equation: 16Li + S8 ⇌ 8Li2S. Calculated based on the conversion potential of 2.15 V vs. Li/Li+, a high theoretical energy density of 2600 W h kg−1 can be realized [12,13]. Different from Li-S battery, lithium gas battery utilizes gas electrode as cathode such as oxygen (O2) or carbon dioxide (CO2). For example, the nonaqueous Li-O2 battery, composed of Li anode, aprotic electrolyte, and O2 cathode, works via reducing O2 into Li2O2 at 2.96 V vs. Li/Li+ and subsequently decomposing into O2 through reversible process [14,15]. It exhibits exceptional theoretical energy density of approximately 3600 W h kg−1 [16,17]. Li-CO2 battery works via absorbing and releasing CO2 during discharge-charge processes, making it a viable technology for reversible CO2 fixation [18,19]. The high discharge potential (approximately 2.8 V) and specific energy density (1876 W h kg−1) establish it as a leading contender in the realm of future energy storage [20] (Fig. 2 a). Throughout our discussion, unless specified otherwise, the metal gas battey mentioned below refers to nonaqueous ones. Nevertheless, in terms of practical application, the multi-electron multi-step conversion progress brings about a series of side reactions, resulting in limited conversion efficiency and restricted cycling capacity [21–27]. As featured in Fig. 2(b), the typical issues in Li-S chemistry can be classified into several aspects: poor conductivity, obvious volume expansion/shrinkage, severe ‘shuttling effect’, thus low sulfur utilization, etc. While the major challenges of Li-O2/CO2 batteries can be summarized as following: sluggish kinetics from the oxidation of discharge products, increased overpotential degrading energy output, and parasitic reaction like the corrosion of cathodes and the decomposition of electrolytes caused by reactive oxygen species. In such typical redox reaction, the conversion kinetics across discharge-charge progress is viewed as the key factor largely affecting electrochemical performance. In order to enhance conversion kinetics, multitudes of efforts have been dedicated to cathode catalyst design and exploration on catalytic effect toward diverse redox reaction. As stated, such multiphase and multielectron associated conversion occurrs at the (gas)-liquid-solid interfaces, wherein the migration rate of both ion and electron takes important role on its performance behaviour [28–30]. In initial researches, more efforts are concentrated on carbonaceous material design owing to distinctive electronic conductivity as well as tunable physicochemical property [31–34]. Usually, the pure carbon or its bulk material with intact π–π bond features limited interaction with absorbents, and therefore diverse strategies are employed to enhance chemically-polar feature such as defect engineering, heteroatom doping, or molecule functionalization [35,36]. Large amount of defective location formed on such catalyst acts as chemically active sites to realize efficient interaction with reactant molecules [37]. Besides, the carbon materials are also exploited as conductive substrates to incorporate metal or metal compounds. Compared with carbon substrates, metal or metal compounds with more asymmetric charge distribution over surface deliver chemically enhanced polar-to-polar interaction with absorbed intermediates [38,39]. Herein, we review recently emerging catalysts, and divide them into eight groups based on real catalytic sites, including defect catalyst, single atom catalyst, metal oxide catalyst, metal sulfide catalyst, etc. as shown in Fig. 2(c). Dozens of materials are well developed for optimizing redox reaction in metal battery, such as functionalized carbon materials (e.g., defective carbon, heteroatom doped carbon, etc.), single atoms (e.g., Pt, Co, Ni, Fe, etc.), metal chalcogenides (e.g., M a X b , where M = Mo, Co, Ni, Fe, W, etc., and X = S, Se, Te, etc.), metal oxides (e.g., MnO2, Co3O4, RuO2, CeO2, etc.), MXenes (metal nitrides (e.g., MoN, VN, etc.) and metal carbides (e.g., MoC, WC, Mo2C, etc.)), metal phosphides (e.g., MoP, CoP, Co2P, Ni2P, etc.), and noble metals (e.g., Pt, Au, Ag, etc.) (Fig. 2c). Generally, these catalysts present modified interaction with reactants, intermediates, or discharge products, and thus lower the activation energy required for redox reaction. The advantages and disadvantages of different kinds of catalysts are described in detail, and meanwhie we extend the application into other non-lithium metal batterry, such as sodium and potassium metal battery. Accordingly, we emphasize on their specific catalytic mechanism to explore close relationship between structure and property. It is believed that this review will help researchers to rationally design advanced electrode materials with enhanced catalytic effect for energy storage and conversion devices and beyond. 2 Mechanism exploration on lithium metal battery 2.1 Li-S battery By far, the progress made in Li-S battery significantly deepens our comprehension toward sulfur redox reaction, consequently expediting the pivotal transition from successful laboratory demonstration to practical industry application [40,41]. Apart from lithium sulfur battery, other alkali metal sulfur batteries sharing similar conversion reaction are still in their infancy [42,43]. Here, we will emphasize on Li-S mechanism with main differences from others discussed as well. On the discharging progress, stable-stacked sulfur of eight-atom ring structure (S8) is cleaved to embrace both lithium ions from electrolyte and electrons from the external electrical circuit, and thus reduced into series of polysulfides until the formation of lithium disulfides [44]. It is consensus that Li-S chemistry proceeds through four stages: The first stage means the transformation of solid S8 into liquid Li2S8 at voltage of 2.2–2.3 V. S 8 + 2 Li → Li 2 S 8 The second stage features the voltage transition from high platform of around 2.2 V to a comparably low voltage of about 2.0 V. At this process, Li2S8 transforms into soluble Li2S n (n ≥ 4). Along with the reaction proceeding, the chain length of Li2S n gradually decreases while the quantity increases, leading to an increase in electrolyte viscosity until reaching its maximum at the end of this stage. Li 2 S 8 + 2 Li → Li 2 S 8 - n + Li 2 S n ( n ≥ 4 ) The third stage means the phase transformation of liquid long-order polysulfides into low-order solid sulfides, which occurs at 1.9–2.1 V. It delivers the main capacity output of around three-quarters of the whole theoretical capacity. In this stage, soluble polysulfide Li2S n transforms into insoluble Li2S2 or Li2S. 2 Li 2 S n + ( 2 n - 4 ) Li → n Li 2 S 2 2 Li 2 S n + ( 2 n - 2 ) Li → n Li 2 S The fourth stage is the solid phase transition from Li2S2 to Li2S. Due to the insulation and insolubility of Li2S2 and Li2S, the entire conversion rate is slow with heavily potential polarization. Li 2 S 2 + 2 Li → 2 Li 2 S Indeed, it is widely acknowledged that the disproportionation or comproportionating equilibriums among different polysulfide species, such as S8 2−, S6 2−, S4 2− and S7 2−, S5 2−, S3 2−, are simultaneously occurring due to their close Gibs free energies [45–47]. The soluble high-order polysulfides Li2S n exhibit poor reduction kinetics, causing severe concentration gradient and thus aggravating shuttling effect [48,49]. This shuttling effect together with ineluctable side reaction is the major cause of serious capacity fading and excess use of electrolyte, which is the bottleneck of the practical use of current lithium sulfur battery. Catalytic conversion of polysulfides not only enhances the kinetics of Li-S battery but also alleviates the shuttle effect, and more great effort has been focusing on catalytic sulfur host design visualized in Fig. 3 . Despite of the major research activity being concentrated on Li-based sulfur battery, sulfur electrodes have been also used with other alkali metals, including Na and K. The sulfur redox reaction coupling with different metallic counter-electrodes shares many similarities with the mechanism proposed in Li-S battery. However, the differences in ionic sizes and physicochemical properties of metal cations (e.g., polarizability, charge density, overall charge, and electronegativity) can affect the reaction path and the kinetics of conversion process. In Li-S battery, Li2S, as the most stable solid sulfides, is regarded as final reduction product while discharging. By contrast, unexpected mechanism is observed in Na/K-S cells, where the stable product of discharge is Na2S2/K2S3, for which the further reduction is sluggish [50–54]. 2.2 Li-O2 battery Li-O2 battery can be classified into two categories based on distinct electrolytes: aqueous Li-O2 battery and nonaqueous Li-O2 battery. In aqueous Li-O2 battery, the redox reaction relies on the formation and decomposition of LiOH, which is illustrated as follows [55]. 2 H 2 O + O 2 + 4 e - ⇌ 4 OH - Li + + OH - + H 2 O ⇌ 4 LiOH · H 2 O Nevertheless, aqueous electrolytes induce severe corrosion toward lithium anode, accompanied by self-discharge, resulting in restricted cycling stability and Coulombic efficiency [56]. Compared with aqueous Li-O2, nonaqueous Li-O2 battery is more attractive owing to superior discharging-charging behavior and thus high energy output [57]. In nonaqueous Li-O2 battery, two kinds of reaction pathways for O2 reduction are proposed with the formation of Li2O2 as final conversion product [54,58]. Firstly, O2 is reduced into LiO2 over catalytic surface based on the reaction: Li + + e - + O 2 → LiO 2 . As formed LiO2 is either absorbed on surface or dissolved into electrolyte, which depends on the Gibbs free energy for LiO2 dissolved in solution (ΔG dis) and LiO2* onto electrode surface (ΔG sur) [59,60]. If the ΔG dis is lower than ΔG sur, the LiO2 is more likely to be dissolved into electrolyte solution. Li ( sol ) + + e - + O 2 ( sol ) ⇌ Li ( sol ) + + O 2 ( sol ) - Li ( sol ) + + 2 O 2 ( sol ) - ⇌ Li 2 O 2 + O 2 2 Li ( sol ) + + 2 O 2 ( sol ) - ⇌ 2 LiO 2 Or, the LiO2* is absorbed over electrode surface while the ΔG sur is lower than ΔG dis. Li + + e - + O 2 ( sol ) ⇌ 2 LiO 2 ∗ Li + + LiO 2 ∗ + e - ⇌ Li 2 O 2 ∗ 2 LiO 2 ∗ ⇌ Li 2 O 2 ∗ + O 2 The final conversion product upon two reaction pathways is insoluble solid Li2O2, which shows poor decomposition kinetics and thus leads to high overpotential and low energy efficiency [61,62]. To enhance electrochemical performance, advanced catalysts are introduced to air cathode to boost both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). In this review, we discuss the recent development of catalyst design with particular emphasis on specific structure as well as catalytic effect. Apart from Li-O2 battery, Na/K-O2 batteries are also considered as great alternatives to current lithium ion battery. By coupling with diverse metal anodes, O2 redox reaction exhibits varied conversion kinetics, thereby resulting in different conversion products associated with different shapes of galvanostatic potential profiles [63–65]. 2.3 Li-CO2 battery Li-CO2 battery was initially introduced alongside the Li-O2 battery by utilizing a mixed gas of O2/CO2 as active cathode, paired with 1 M LiTFSI electrolyte in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) (3:7 v/v) [66–68]. At such circumstance, the conversion voltage upon discharge-charge progress resembles to that of Li-O2 battery, sparking speculation that the oxygen is the only reduced species. Nevertheless, the discharge capacity is almost three times as that from standard Li-O2 battery. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra revealed O2∙− can be captured by CO2 and thus Li2CO3 is the main discharge product. The reaction progress of mixed cathode (O2 and CO2) is proposed as follows. 2 O 2 + 4 e - → 4 O · 2 - O · 2 - + CO 2 → CO · 4 - CO · 4 - + CO 2 → C 2 O · 6 - C 2 O · 6 - + O · 2 - → C 2 O 6 2 - + O 2 C 2 O 6 2 - + 2 O · 2 - + 4 Li + → 2 Li 2 CO 3 + 2 O 2 Subsequently, Archer et al. reported a primary Li-CO2 battery in which pure CO2 was adopted as cathode material [69]. However, this Li-CO2 battery only showed good discharge capacity at high temperature [70]. Later, Chen’s group reported a true reversible Li-CO2 battery based on the reaction 4Li + 3CO2 → 2Li2CO3 + C at room temperature [71]. Although the pathway is still controversial, the possible mechanism of discharge process is assumed as follows [72]. 2 CO 2 + 2 e - → C 2 O 4 2 - C 2 O 4 2 - → CO 2 2 - + CO 2 C 2 O 4 2 - + CO 2 2 - → 2 CO 3 2 - + C 2 Li + + CO 3 2 - → Li 2 CO 3 However, the formed insoluble Li2CO3 would accumulate on the cathode upon cycling, decreasing the catalytic activity of cathode catalyst and deteriorating the battery performance [55,73]. Moreover, as a wide bandgap insulator, Li2CO3 is very stable (Δf G 0 = 1132 kJ mol−1), so its decomposition requires high charging potential, which can be proposed as following. 2 Li 2 CO 3 → 4 Li + + 2 CO 2 + 2 O 2 - + 3 e - Such high proceeding potential would induce side reaction, such as the decomposition of electrolyte and polymer binder, deteriorating the cycle life of Li-CO2 battery [9]. To overcome these issues, significant efforts are dedicated to the development of highly efficient electrocatalysts. This review focuses on the emerging advancement made in the design of electrocatalysts for high-performance Li-CO2 battery, which can be also extended into other application such as Na/K-CO2 battery. Above-mentioned main mechanism in diverse metal battery has been well compared in Fig. 4 , and it is found the catalytic material exploration plays vital role in high-performance battery. 3 Catalytic effect in lithium metal battery As described by Arrhenius equation ( k = A e - E a / R T ), the reaction rate is closely associated with activation energy barrier [30,74]. Conversion progress can be accelerated via lowering energy barrier, which is normally accomplished by using suitable catalysts [75]. Targeting lithium metal battery, the emerging catalysts are categorized into two kinds: heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts [76]. Recent growing high-quality characterization especially the operando testing suggests us a platform to realize a close correlation between material structure and its enhanced catalytic effect. This review aims to provide a systematic exploration of design aspects toward heterogeneous catalysts, focusing specifically on their unique catalytic mechanism. Additionally, a concise introduction to homogeneous catalysts will be included for comparative purposes. 3.1 Heterogeneous catalysts Heterogeneous electrocatalysts are commonly applied in cathode electrode in metal-sulfur/gas batteries, which provide catalytic hetero-interface for electrochemical reaction. As mentioned, the typical redox reaction in cathode electrode involves both electron and mass transferring and thus it is highly recommended that the cathode catalysts possess high conductivity such as carbon-based materials [77–79]. Porous carbon has received considerable attention due to large specific surface area and abundant channels, enriching reaction active sites toward adsorbent molecules [79]. For instance, Ketjen black with relatively high catalytic activity and excellent electronic conductivity is applied as cathode catalyst in rechargeable Li-CO2 battery [71]. However, the catalytic efficiency of pure porous carbon is still limited and as realized Li-gas battery is far from satisfactory. While toward the application of metal sulfur battery, the porous carbon usually acts as sulfur host to restrict sulfur escaping out of cathode while accelerating conversion reaction [80,81]. Similarly, due to its restricted chemically polar reactivity, pure carbon cannot well control sulfur redox reaction over surface. By far, various endeavors are focusing on modifying the polar surfaces by introducing dopants such as B, N, and S, or combining them with other nanostructured transition metals or metallic compounds. In this section, we will outline the significant progress made in heterogeneous catalysts, with a particular emphasis on the specific catalytic mechanism and diverse catalytic centers involved. Accordingly, we categorize the actual catalytic centers into eight distinct types: defect catalyst, single atom catalyst, metal oxides/chalcogenides/MXenes/phosphides, metal catalyst, and others. We will systematically discuss the composition characteristics, advantages, and disadvantages of each type of catalytic centers. 3.1.1 Defect catalyst The catalysis efficiency is influenced by the physicochemical property of active interface, which is further decided by the electronic configuration of both catalytic sites and reaction intermediates [82,83]. Commonly, intact carbon or bulk carbon materials with symmetrical atom arrangement deliver chemically non-polar interaction with absorbents, impacting their catalytic efficiency [84]. Defect engineering, one popular strategy to introduce chemically polar location as catalytic sites, has been widely applied in both carbon and noncarbon materials toward lithium-sulfur/gas battery [85,86]. Generally, defects with unsaturated electronic occupation modify orbit overlapping with reactants, which induces electronic redistribution and hence modifies reaction kinetics. Summarized over past research, defect active sites can be divided into several categories including carbon defects, anion vacancies, cation vacancies, dislocations, stepped surfaces, boundaries, etc. [87]. In this section, we fristly focus on non-metal defect catalyst, such as defective carbon, and then extend into anion and cation defects in metal-based materials. Position in carbon deficiency via heteroatom doping serves as catalytic active sites toward diverse redox reactions owing to chemically polar nature from delocalized π electron [88,89]. For example, double-shelled carbon spheres, doped with nitrogen and phosphorus, are reported as sulfur host to modulate Li-S chemistry [90]. The introduced carbon defects on the carbon spheres along with heteroatoms N and P serve as catalytic centrals to facilitate both the formation and decomposition of Li2S. Similarly, hierarchical N doping carbon with enriched mesopores and macro channels is reported as efficient cathodes for Li-O2 battery [91]. The C-N defective sites greatly facilitate the Li+ diffusion and electrolyte immersion, meanwhile creating an effective space for O2 diffusion and O2/Li2O2 conversion. The lithiated pyridinic N suggests enhanced O2 adsorption capability and catalytic efficiency based on the following reaction. Li + + PyriCS → LiPyriCS + LiPyriCS + + e - → LiPyriCS LiPyriCS + O 2 → LiPyriCSO 2 where LiPyriCS represents lithiated PyriCS. Also, porous B doped graphite is verified to be effective electrode to boost oxygen redox process [92]. Thus formed B-C defective sites activate electrons in the carbon π system, and meanwhile accelerate the breaking of Li–O bond to decompose Li2O2 owing to optimized interaction over Li5O6 clusters. Furthermore, B–O functional groups linking to the carbon surface or edge serve as additional reaction sites to facilitate ORR progress. The introduction of defective carbon not only takes effect on Li-S/O2 chemistry, but also boosts conversion kinetics in Li-CO2 battery [93]. It is demonstrated recently that oxygen-containing functional groups in graphene aerogel can stabilize CO2-related intermediate species and thus improve the catalytic activity through a synergistic coupling effect with N dopants [94]. In addition to the defects induced by heteroatoms, edge location, derived from the edge enriched graphitic carbon as well as carbon quantum dots, naturally acts as chemically active sites to promote redox reaction toward lithium metal battery [95,96]. For instance, edge enriched B, N-co-doped holey graphene is successfully applied as catalyst to promote CO2 redox reaction [97]. The initial discharge-charge profiles show reduced overpotential along with prolonged plateau. Recently, another carbonaceous material consisting of carbon quantum dots decorated on holey graphene emerges as efficient catalyst to promote the formation and decomposition of Li2CO3 [98]. Besides, to further explore the catalytic effect from diverse defect structures, Jiang and co-workers carefully designed five representative defective structures, including single vacancy (SV), two pentagons and one octagon (DV5-8–5), three pentagons and three heptagons (DV555-777), four pentagons, one hexagon, and four heptagons (DV5555-6-7777), and Stone-Wales (SW) defects, and meanwhile compared adsorption energies of O2 and Li as well as Li4O4 growing pathways over surface [99,100]. It is found that presence of DV5555-6-7777 and SW defects is beneficial for nonaqueous Li-O2 battery because DV5555-6-7777 and SW defects exhibit zero-band-gap semiconductor behavior, ensuring excellent electronic conductivity. Apart from carbon defects, defective active sites also appear in non-carbon materials such as metal/metal compounds. Generally, metal centers serving as catalytically active sites show enhanced interaction with reactants and thus facilitate conversion kinetics by modifying reaction energy barrier [101,102]. This interaction over interface or catalysis efficiency is largely influenced by specific coordination environment around central metal atoms. Considering this aspect, defect engineering such as anion vacancy is applied to change electronic distribution surrounding active centrals and hence modify chemical interaction with adsorbent intermediates [103,104]. For example, sulfur deficiency in MoS2− x is verified to increase the electron density around metal centers, which facilitates the reduction of sulfur into polysulfides probably through the evolution of some metastable S x ∙− species [105]. Similarly, the oxygen deficiency in metal oxides is also explored as enhanced catalytic location applied in lithium metal battery. It is reported oxygen adsorption over oxygen-deficient MnO2 surface would elongate the O–O bond, which is utilized to activate partial dissociation of O2. In addition to the anion deficiency, cation ion vacancy is also constructed among various catalysts to modulate charge distribution so as to enhance catalytic activity [106–108]. The strategy of optimal catalyst design made in lithium metal battery can be also traced in other alkali battery. It is found that a high concentration of cation vacancies in transitional metal oxides could enhance intercalation and conversion capacity for fast alkali metal storage. For instance, Ti deficiency in 2D unilamellar lepidocrocite-type titanium oxide realizes highly reversible Na ion intercalation without phase and structural change [109]. As verified by density functional theory (DFT), the energy barrier for Na ion transferring over deficiency-enriched surface obviously decreases, suggesting a much more favorable diffusion of Na ions (Fig. 5 a). It is significant progress in Na metal battery, as the main difference between Li and Na battery is the larger atom radium, which brings about more sluggish kinetics upon cycling process. Defect location not only has impact on its closely surrounding couple ions, but also exists in substrate materials to further vary electronic structure of catalysts implemented over surface. As a typical example, oxygen vacancies in anatase TiO2 introduced by molybdenum doping allow better electron transfer from the support surface to Pt catalyst, thereby facilitating the oxygen dissociation reaction (Fig. 5b) [110]. In addition, a notable study discovered that a synergistic effect from a combination of inner oxygen vacancies and the external Co3+/Co2+ ratio results in an enhanced catalytic activity of Co3O4, as illustrated in Fig. 5(c) [111]. The results of X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) indicate that a great deal of oxygen vacancies exist in the interior and more Co3+ ions are formed on the outer surface of Co3O4 nanosheets. This optimized electronic structure could enhance the electrocatalytic activity of Co3O4 for ORR. Apart from above-discussed defects, other types, for example, lattice dislocations, stepped surfaces, boundaries etc., also notably enhance the catalytic activities of catalysts applied in alkali metal batteries. An illustrative instance presented by Song et al. showcases the significant influence of surface structure on the catalytic performance of Pt catalyst. While pristine Pt demonstrates limited catalytic activity towards OER, Pt surfaces enriched with high-index {411} facets exhibit robust catalytic capabilities for both OER and ORR. This pronounced enhancement can be attributed to the presence of numerous step edges, kink sites, and ledge sites on the high-index facets, thereby enabling larger surface energy (0.29 eV Å−2) and O-binding energy (1.48 eV) [112] (Fig. 5d). Overall, defect engineering with easy-synthesis feature shows great promising for generalization and commercialization, while more controllable techniques for generating ordered defect structures are required in future toward practical application. 3.1.2 Single atom catalyst In some cases, single atoms as active sites are implanted into defective location of substrate materials, which thereby can be regarded as one kind of defect catalysts [113,114]. In other cases, single atoms are grown onto the surface of base materials via chemically polar interaction [114,115]. Compared with other metals or metal compounds, single atom catalyst delivers maximized utilization of exposed metal atoms due to the downsize of metals to atomic level, thereby lowering the required metal content [116]. In addition, owing to the distinctive orbital gaps between the highest energy occupied and lowest energy unoccupied molecular, single atom catalyst exhibits increased chemical polarity and affinity toward sulfides or oxides intermediates. Two-dimensional (2D) layered carbonaceous materials with large specific surface area and fast electron/ion conductivity are widely explored as substrates for single atoms implanting [117–119]. In such heterostructure, center metal ions (such as Co, Fe, Ni, Pt, Ru, Ir, etc.) with unsaturated d-orbital realize appropriate symmetry matching with anti-bond σ-orbital or anti-bond π-orbital of reactant molecules [120,121]. For example, as a favored single atom catalyst, cobalt has been dedicatedly constructed into diverse porous carbon materials, which suggest highly catalytic activity in lithium metal battery [122]. Wan’s group achieved successful integration of single atom cobalt into nitrogen-doped graphene (Co-N-C), utilizing it as a bifunctional catalyst for the conversion of polysulfides (Fig. 6 a) [123]. DFT calculations were employed to compare the Gibbs free energies of polysulfides redox reaction over N-C and Co-N-C surface. The corresponding results reveal a lower Gibbs free energy from Co-N-C substrate, which indicates that the reduction of sulfur is more thermodynamically favorable over Co-N-C skeleton. In addition to nitrogen-doped carbon, other functionalized carbon materials, such as boron-doped, sulfur-doped, and phosphorus-doped carbon, are also utilized as support matrices for single atoms [124]. For example, Guo’s group incorporated Co single atom into N, B co-doped porous carbon through a soft template self-assembly pyrolysis method and then employed it as catalyst for OER and ORR processes [125]. They found that the presence of boron allows for abundant electron-deficient sites, which facilitate electron transfer around the coordination centers and then strengthen the interaction with oxygen intermediates (Fig. 6b). Compared to monometallic single atom catalyst, dual metal single atom catalysts with bimetallic active sites display enhanced catalytic activity due to synergistic interactions involving the cooperation of two adjacent atomic metal species [126]. Recently, various bimetallic single atom catalysts have been successfully developed and demonstrated high performance toward diverse redox reactions, including Fe-Co, Fe-Ni, Co-Zn, Ni-Co, Fe-Mn, etc. [127–131]. For instance, Zhu’s group prepared an enhanced Fe-Co bimetallic catalyst utilizing soft template-directed interlayer confinement route [132], where Fe and Co single atoms are stabilized separately on 2D carbon nanosheets via coordination with N and S heteroatoms to form a FeN4S1/CoN4S1 configuration (Fig. 6c). DFT calculation reveals larger working potential from Co sites than Fe active sites in Fe-Co dual single atom catalyst, surpassing corresponding single atom catalyst, confirming better catalytic activity. Although substantial compositional diversity has been achieved in single atom catalyst over diverse configurations, metal single atoms are generally dispersed randomly and uncontrollably on substrates, leading to a lack of electronic synergy among metal active sites [133,134]. More recently, an emerging class of catalysts containing adjacent single metal atoms with atomic site-to-site interaction has been reported with unique geometric features and enhanced electrocatalytic performance. Unlike the supported metallic clusters/nanoparticles which have fixed structures with closely packed geometries, the correlated metal single atoms exhibit various geometric structures, showcasing greater flexibility in adjusting the electronic and electrocatalytic properties of individual atoms [135–138]. For example, short-range ordered Ir single atoms integrated in the cobalt oxide spinel lattice exhibit Ir–Ir interaction, which modulates electronic states of active sites and results in exceptional electrocatalytic activity in acidic OER (Fig. 6d) [139]. In short, single-atomic catalysts, with their highest atom utilization and controllable electronic configuration, play an important role in future catalyst application. However, single-atomic catalysts have more unsaturated dangling bonds showing stronger chemical activity and therefore are easy to reunite, so a more uniform distribution with increased atom loading remains a challenge to overcome in the future development of single atom catalyst. 3.1.3 Metal oxide catalyst Metal oxides consist of metal cation coupling with oxygen anion in the oxidation state of O2−, thereby realizing stronger chemically polar interface toward reactant molecules [44,140,141]. Transition metal oxides including both noble and non-noble metal oxides are widely used as catalysts in diverse energy storage and conversion systems, of which the catalytic activity is closely associated with d-electron configuration as well as lattice oxygen characteristic [142–144]. Over past, a series of non-noble metal oxides typically including Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, VO2, V2O3, V2O5, MnO2, Fe3O4, MoO3, Nb2O5, etc. are thoroughly investigated and make substantial progress in high-performance metal sulfur battery [145–147]. In early stage, Tao and co-workers found that ultra-fine Nb2O5 nanocrystals can accelerate the electrochemical kinetics in Li-S battery [148]. Such improved kinetics is confirmed by cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests performed at different sweep rates, as shown in Fig. 7 (a). The conversion behavior is evaluated based on the equation as following [149]. i = a v b where i is current; υ is sweep rate; a and b are adjustable parameters and b is related to Li+ diffusion. In addition, the log i and log υ are strict linear relationship with b value as their slope. According to Fig. 7(a), b I (b value of cathodic peak I) is always larger than b II (b-value of cathodic peak II), implying that the reaction of S8 to Li2S6/Li2S4 is faster than the reaction of Li2S6/Li2S4 to Li2S2/Li2S. It is worth noting that b value increases significantly when ultra-fine Nb2O5 nanocrystals are introduced, indicating fast conversion rate derived from improved kinetics. Moreover, ultra-fine Nb2O5 nanocrystals exhibit strong chemical adsorption toward Li2S6 molecules with binding energy of 65.16 kcal mol−1, which is about 6 times larger than that from sp 2 carbon. Besides, Ma et al. demonstrated the inserted polar and electrocatalytic CeO2 can efficiently solve the hurdle of polysulfides dissolution and further promote redox reaction shown as Fig. 7(b) [150]. Theoretical simulations verify the strong interaction between CeO2 nanocrystals and polysulfides with adsorption energy much higher than those of pristine carbon or other polar materials. More recently, Wu’s group carefully constructed CeO2− x catalyst with an appropriate concentration of oxygen vacancies, which endows fast redox reaction [151]. Based on theoretical simulation, at interface between Li2S6 and CeO2, two Li atoms in Li2S6 form two Li–O bonds with two O atoms on CeO2 surface with bond length of 1.89 and 1.90 Å, respectively, and one S atom adjacent to the Li atom forms a Ce–S bond with a bond length of 3.00 Å. The adsorption energy for Li2S6 over CeO2 is −2.36 eV. By contrast, enabled by oxygen deficiency modified CeO2− x , apart from two Li–O bonds with bond length of 1.95 and 2.09 Å, the S atom in Li2S6 forms three Ce–S bonds with Ce atoms on the CeO2− x surface with bond length of 2.76, 2.78, and 2.83 Å, respectively. The more Ce–S bonds with shorter bond length indicate the enhanced interaction between Li2S6 and CeO2− x due to the oxygen deficiencies. Consistently, the adsorption energy for Li2S6 onto CeO2− x increases to −3.82 eV. The higher adsorption energy indicates that oxygen vacancies enhance the chemisorption capability of CeO2− x toward polysulfides (Fig. 7c) [151]. Compared with low-cost non-noble metal oxides, noble metal oxides such as IrO2 and RuO2 are mainly investigated in the application of O2/CO2 redox reaction. Typically, RuO2, a representative catalyst toward OER process, is widely explored in Li-O2 battery, and more recently, it is demonstrated to be a cathode material for Li-CO2 to realize catalytic decomposition of Li2CO3 (Fig. 7d) [152]. As a typical example, Xu and co-workers reported monodisperse RuO2 supported on layered double oxides, and while being utilized as cathode catalyst toward Li-CO2, it exhibits ultralow charging platform at around 3.9 V [153]. To realize substantive potential of Li-O2 battery, not only should OER be accelerated, but more importantly oxygen reduction with relatively higher conversion barrier should be simultaneously alleviated [58,154,155]. In such circumstance, RuO2 catalysts are utilized to combine with other cathode catalysts which deliver catalytic activity toward ORR, for example MnO2 [156–158]. For instance, Lee and co-workers reported RuO2/MnO2 decorated on carbon nanotubes as the cathode applied in Li-O2 battery. It shows enhanced bifunctional catalytic efficiency in both the ORR and OER and it also completely decomposes LiOH and Li2CO3 byproducts that may exist in discharged electrodes (Fig. 7e) [159]. Obviously, restricted by poor electrical conductivity, pure oxides are hard to independently function as catalysts in alkali metal battery; instead, most are combined with carbonaceous materials [148,150,152]. Thus, the construction of more effective interface between them is very important. Additionally, compared to single-atomic catalyst, the catalytic activity is decreased by the small surface area of bulk structure as well as limited exposure of active sites. In future, those metal oxides catalysts with more catalytic sites per mass unit and increased activity per active site are eagerly anticipated [159]. 3.1.4 Metal chalcogenides catalyst Metal chalcogenides, commonly consisting of transition metal ions coupling by S, Se, Te, etc., are emerging as another significant class to accelerate redox reaction toward alkali metal battery [160–163]. Taking metal sulfides as an example, just similar to their oxides counterparts, the catalytic efficiency is ascribed to both positive metal centres and negative sulfur ions with diverse coordination. Usually, the metallic centers with modified electronic configuration give rise to enhanced interaction toward adsorbent molecules, while the soft basic (e.g., S2 2− ions) covalent nature renders decent electrical conductivity, which both show significant aid in maintaining highly catalytic activity and high-capacity retention. The utilization of chemically reactive metal sulfides as sulfur hosts has become increasingly important in recent years for effective polysulfides regulation, mainly including TiS2, VS2, Co x S y , ZrS2, Mo x S y , WS2, Ni3S2, Sb2S3, etc. [164–168]. Cobalt sulfides, with notable conductivity and 2D lamella structure, have been confirmed as reliable host material to facilitate intimate contact via S n 2−–Co δ + and Li+–S δ − bond. For instance, hollow polar Co9S8 is identified as enhanced sulfur host to realize reversible sulfur redox reaction in Li-S battery (Fig. 8 a) [169]. The first-principle calculation is used to confirm the improved chemisorption of polysulfides onto (311) and (440) planes of Co9S8. As illustrated in Fig. 8(a), Li can make bond with S on the Co9S8 surface, while S can also make bond with Co on Co9S8 surface based on normal Coulomb interaction between cations and anions. Interestingly, binding energies on the (311) surface are higher than those on the (440) surface, suggesting more sufficient adsorption capability from (311) surface. Besides, the corresponding dissociation barriers between Li and S of polysulfides on both (311) and (440) Co9S8 surfaces are lower than 0.6 eV, demonstrating enhanced decomposition kinetics over Co9S8 surfaces. Apart from Co9S8, other cobalt sulfides with diverse cation-anion coupling coordination such as CoS, CoS2, and Co4S3 are also explored as efficient sulfur hosts to enhance catalysis and adsorption performance. Recently, He’s group proposed defective graphene modified CoS nanosheets, which deliver high catalytic activity toward sulfur conversion reaction [170]. The exposed CoS at the defective sites of graphene exhibits stronger polysulfides anchoring-catalyzing capability, along with high-flux Li+ and fast electron transfer from the circumjacent graphene (Fig. 8b). Resembling to other transitional metal compounds, nano-engineering such as heterostructure engineering, defect engineering, as well as dopant engineering, is commonly considered to modulate the electronic configuration for enhancing catalytic effect [67,171,172]. For instance, Yuan’s group developed Cu-doped CoS2 nanoparticles by facile solvothermal method and then evaluated as cathode catalysts for Li-O2 battery [173]. It is revealed that doping Cu heteroatoms into CoS2 lattice can increase the covalency property of Co–S bond with more electron transfer from Co 3d to S 3p orbit, thereby resulting in less electron transfer from Co 3d to O 2p orbit from Li-O species. It weakens the adsorption strength toward Li-O intermediates, decreases the reaction barrier, and then improves the catalytic performance in Li-O2 battery (Fig. 8c). Apart from cobalt chalcogenides, there are increasing iron/nickel/molybdenum-based catalysts applied in Li-CO2 battery, allowing for superior CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and evolution reaction (CO2ER) [174–177]. For instance, Zhou’s group recently designed a bidirectional catalyst of vertically growing MoS2 onto Co9S8 supported by carbon paper. The abundant edges of this catalyst as active sites facilitate both CO2RR and CO2ER, while the vertical hetero-structure improves the interfacial conductivity and modulates the electron transportation pathway along the basal planes [174]. Similarly, such hetero-structure also suggests great promise in higher catalytic activity and reduced cell overpotential toward Na-CO2 battery [175–177]. It is demonstrated recently that insertion of SnS2 could reduce the overpotential and improve the cyclic stability compared to pristine MoS2 [175]. Na-CO2 battery with the MoS2/SnS2 cathode catalyst realizes a discharge capacity of 35889 mA h g−1, which is stable up to 100 discharge-charge cycles as the prepared catalyst successfully decomposes Na2CO3 [175]. Although intensive catalysts with diverse electronic configuration have been carefully designed, the responsible relationship between the electronic structure and catalytic activity remains unclear, which however shows high promise for future catalyst design [178,179]. Most recently, Zhang’s group reported a fundamental study on how the adsorption of polysulfides determines catalytic activity [180]. By examining the activity of a series of transition metal dopants (Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Cu2+) into ZnS lattice, they found that strengthening adsorption does not necessarily lead to the enhancement of catalytic activity. Especially when the desorption of discharged polysulfides (Li2S2/Li2S) is rate limiting, the strong adsorption of Li2S2/Li2S may induce the passivation of catalysts (Fig. 8d). Only medium adsorption of polysulfides can enhance the conversion of Li2S4 and meanwhile facilitate the desorption of Li2S2/Li2S, thereby showing the highest catalytic activity. This work makes a significant contribution in deciphering electronic configuration, binding energy, as well as catalytic effect, suggesting a guideline in future catalyst design. Compared with metal oxides, metal chalcogenide catalysts suggest enhanced electronic conductivity as well as the ion transferring capability. Besides, it seems that metal chalcogenides are more easily to convert into thin layered structure with large specific surface area, conducive to the exposure of active sites. In future, more efficient composite materials with robust structure are required for metal chalcogenide catalysts to achieve highly catalytic efficiency in practical application. 3.1.5 Mxenes catalyst Owing to the fast electronic transferability as well as excellent physiochemical stability even under challenging condition, MXenes, including transition metal nitrides and carbides, are well suited for a variety of energy-related applications [181–184]. Particularly, both generalized gradient approximation and local density approximation analysis reveal their metallic behavior with no resolved band gap [185–188]. In early research, transitional metal nitrides, such as VN, TiN, NbN, MoN, etc., are developed as efficient host materials to regulate sulfur redox reaction [13,184]. Ren et al. prepared the Co-doped VN yolk-shell nanospheres coated by N-doped carbon via solvothermal and calcination methods and then employed it as sulfur host [188]. Benefiting from enhanced catalytic effect and chemisorption toward polysulfides, the prepared cell exhibits excellent cycling performance of 600 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at 1 C. To advance this progress, Zhong and co-workers designed porous carbon fibers/vanadium nitride arrays through facile solvothermal method [189]. The enhanced conversion kinetics is revealed by the CV results, in which obvious positive shift in reduction process and negative shift in oxidation process are observed. With high sulfur loading of 8.1 mg cm−2, it realizes high reversible capacity of 1052.5 mA h g−1 after 250 cycles at 0.1 C. Ma et al. reported porous-shell vanadium nitride nanobubbles as sulfur host, of which the strong affinity toward polysulfides is verified by theoretical simulation [190]. As calculated, the binding energies of S8, Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2, and Li2S over the (200) surface of VN are −2.21, −3.46, −3.01, −3.27, −3.14, and −3.86 eV, respectively, which are comparable or higher than that of other metal compounds (Fig. 9 a). Besides, Jeong et al. developed TiN catalyst to modulate sulfur redox reaction in Li-S battery and meanwhile carefully explored its catalytic mechanism by combining theoretical calculation and experiment results [191]. It is found that short-order polysulfides are more stable than the long-order polysulfides (n ≥ 4 in Li2S n ) while TiN is introduced, and the formation energy with and without TiN can be arranged as follows. E f S - TiN Li 2 S n - E f molecule Li 2 S n = E ( Li 2 S n @ S - TiN ) - E S - TiN - E ( Li 2 S n ) It illustrates that the fragmentation of long-order polysulfides into short ones is more likely to occur over TiN surface. More recently, Li et al. successfully prepared mesoporous niobium nitride microspheres/N-doped graphene hybrids and utilized it as catalytic host for sulfur cathode [192]. As verified, NbN microspheres chemically immobilize polysulfides via efficient Nb–S bonds and meanwhile promote fast reduction into insoluble Li2S, enabling enhanced reaction kinetics (Fig. 9b). Moreover, the highly conductive NbN and N-doped graphene nanosheets provide rapid electronic transferring, and consequently large capacity, high rate capability, and long cycle life are realized based on NbN/graphene hybrid host. In addition to metal nitrides, metal carbides also take great effect in polysulfides conversion reaction via heterogeneous catalytic effect and then inhibit the shuttling issue in metal sulfur battery [40,193,194]. As a typical example, Razaq et al. dispersed Mo2C onto carbon nanotubes and used it as sulfur host for Li-S battery [195]. They found that the originally yellow colored Li2S4 turns into colorless one after the addition of Mo2C, verifying its strong adsorptive capability. Besides, CV curves from symmetrical cells show increased current density from Mo2C/CNT, suggesting accelerated conversion kinetics. Such catalytic behavior of molybdenum carbides toward sulfur redox reaction is not constrained to Li-S battery, but also well demonstrated in other alkali metal sulfur batteries [196,197]. For instance, Yu et al. deliberately designed hierarchical porous hollow carbon polyhedrons embedded with uniform Mo2C nanoparticles as the host for S in Na-S battery. It is confirmed that highly conductive Mo2C realizes strong chemical adsorption toward polysulfides and then catalyzes transformation reaction, which can effectively inhibit the dissolution issue and accelerate the reaction kinetics [196]. In addition, Mo2C as cathode catalyst also shows great promise for Li-O2/CO2 battery. For example, Kundu et al. used facile solvothermal-calcination method to prepare carbon-free Mo2C fibers [198]. When used as air cathode, a remarkably low charging potential, on which about 90% voltage is less than 3.5 V in tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME) and even lower than 3.3 V for dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), is observed. During the ORR process, a Li x MoO3 layer would form at the interface of carbon and Li2O2 based on the reaction as following. x / 2 Li 2 O 2 + MoO 2 + δ → Li x MoO 3 where the MoO2+ δ is derived from the partial oxidation of Mo2C surface, x is about 0.5 based on the XPS analysis. Different from insulating and insoluble Li2CO3 that was formed at the interface between carbon and Li2O2, the Li x MoO3 would be simultaneously oxidized with Li2O2. However, continuous oxidization of Li x MoO3 would lead to viscous electrolyte, largely damaging cycle span. To solve this problem, Sun et al. adopted N-doped carbon coated Mo2C nanorods in which the N-doped carbon can decrease partial Li x MoO3 formation (Fig. 9c) [199]. In order to compare the catalytic capability among diverse metal carbides, Yang and co-workers constructed a series of 3d transition metal carbides templated by NaCl thus to compare their catalytic activity in Li-O2 battery [200]. Taking overpotential as criteria to measure catalytic activity, some intrinsic properties related to catalytic behavior are determined, including adsorption energies of Li and LiO2, surface energy, and binding energy of O. The theoretical calculation results indicate that TiC suggests smaller ORR and OER overpotential, mainly owing to moderate binding energy toward O* atom (Fig. 9d). Thus, it can be seen that MXenes catalyst usually allows for much higher electronic transferring than metal oxides, which is beneficial for the typical redox reaction. But it is challenging for MXenes to produce a dedicated nanostructure, particularly those with large specific surface area. Future research will focus on synthesis techniques and more efficient composite architectures. 3.1.6 Metal phosphides catalyst Transition metal phosphides consist of metal cation as well as phosphorus anion with diverse chemical formula, such as MoP, CoP, Co2P etc., portrait metalloid character along with rich bonding type themselves, and thus they also suggest great promise toward diverse alkali metal batteries [201–203]. As a representative example, Huang and co-workers constructed FeP as electrocatalytically active sites to modulate sulfur redox reaction [204]. As demonstrated, the adsorption energies of S8, Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2, and Li2S species over the (111) plane of FeP are calculated to be −3.37, −2.83, −3.18, −2.80, −2.42, and −1.98 eV, respectively, suggesting stronger chemical anchoring capability (Fig. 10 a). Such optimized interaction between sulfides species and metal phosphides is also unveiled by Qian’s group, and they systematically studied the kinetic behaviors of Li-S chemistry on Co-based compounds with fixed metal cation and varied non-metal anions, including Co3O4, CoS2, Co4N, and CoP [205]. The p band center in CoP has a distinct upshift with respect to Fermi level, thus enabling a reduced energy gap between the cobalt 3d and anion 2p band center (as shown in Fig. 10b). The anion of the P atom is softer and less electron-pulling than O and S atoms, resulting in an increased energy of bonding states and a reduced energy gap between the bonding and antibonding orbitals. This further gives rise to higher electron energy, due to anions with more hybridization and a contribution to the valence band electron, which thus facilitates the electron exchange to promote interfacial S6 2−/S2− redox dynamics. Besides, the enhanced catalytic activity from optimized electronic configuration of metal phosphides is applied to accelerate gas evolution reaction [203,206–208]. For example, while CoP is utilized as cathode catalyst for Li-O2 battery, as obtained battery shows good discharge capacity of 2994 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 and high round-trip efficiency of over 90% [209]. In addition, Wei et al. coated MoP nanoflakes onto the surface of carbon cloth through in situ growth method and then used it as a binder-free electrode for nonaqueous Li-O2 battery [210]. The MoP electrode exhibits improved discharge/charge capability of 4.15 mAh at 0.1 mA without capacity fading during 400 cycles (Fig. 10c). In a later study, they reported a three-dimensional (3D) free-standing film as highly efficient oxygen electrode, in which MoP quantum dots are embedded into N, P-codoped hollow carbon fiber [211]. They performed systematic studies on the interaction between MoP and oxygen using DFT calculation method, and the results show that the (100) crystal facet allows for enhanced adsorption for O2, leading to superior catalytic activity towards ORR and OER processes (Fig. 10d). In addition, the N, P-codoped hollow carbon fiber with open end offers fast transfer channels for electrons and lithium ions. Consequently, as obtained MoP exhibits higher discharge specific capacity of 6.75 mA h cm−2 and a lower charge voltage of < 3.85 V. Similarly, transition metal phosphides such as ruthenium phosphides make important contribution in metal carbon dioxide battery [212–215]. Over past, RuP2 uniformly deposited onto N, P dual-doped carbon are dedicatedly designed and applied in Li-CO2 battery. Owing to its superior electrical conductivity, high electrochemical stability, and enough ion/electron and space for the reversible reaction, a superior reversible discharge capacity of 11951 mA h g−1 with excellent cyclability for more than 200 cycles and low overpotentials (<1.3 V) is realized at the fixed capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 (Fig. 10e). From above discussion, we can see transition metal phosphides deliver excellent conductivity, providing fast electron transfer channels. In addition, they typically exhibit desirable stability in the application of energy storage and conversion. Furthermore, abundant resources and low-cost benefits make them the most promising catalytic materials for future application. However, effective structural design that contains more active sites with enhanced catalytic activity remains a huge challenge in future. 3.1.7 Metal catalyst Generally, metal catalysts with diverse dimensions can be classified as metal nanoparticles, metal nanoclusters, and single atoms. In this section, we will focus on main metal nanoparticles/clusters catalysts incorporating both precious and transitional metal and corresponding application in alkali metal battery. As previously mentioned, single atom catalysts with maximized atom exposure are under great anticipation to realize more active sites and thus enhance catalytic effect with less mass sacrifice. However, due to relatively higher surface energy, they are more likely to reunite, which compromises their catalytic activity. By contrast, metal nanoparticles suggest more stable physical and chemical properties, and thereby they can be well constructed into a variety of nano-structures or easily composited with one another [216,217]. It has been confirmed that many factors, including chemical composition, electronic configuration, metal-reactant/solvent interaction, and metal/base interaction, have a significant influence on catalytic properties [126,218–220]. Particularly, the outer electronic structure, especially d-orbital electronic, plays decisive role in the catalytic activity of metal catalysts [4,221,222]. Salem et al. found that the uniform dispersion of Pt nanoparticles onto graphene layer demonstrates a 40% enhancement in the specific capacity over pristine graphene due to the modified chemical adsorption toward sulfur/sulfides species, as shown in Fig. 11 (a) [223]. Luo et al. reported Pt-Cu bimetallic electrocatalyst with different weight ratio of Pt and Cu (x% Pt + 5% Cu, x = 2.5, 5, and 10), which are further coated by the CuO [224]. Interestingly, single metal Cu or Pt delivers no catalytic activity toward OER. However, this bimetallic electrocatalysts markedly decrease the charging overpotential to 0.2–0.3 V and the 2.5% Pt + 5% Cu electrode has the lowest charging overpotential about 0.2 V. Lee’s group systematically investigated the catalytic activity of Pt, Pd, and Ru nanoparticles supported on rGO for Li-O2 battery [225]. Through the 1H and 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) analysis, they found that Ru could selectively facilitate Li2− x O2/Li2O2 oxidation reaction, whereas Pt and Pd show no selectivity in their catalytic activity (Fig. 11b). In addition, Wang and co-workers designed a graphene/Au-nanoparticles/Au-nanosheets sandwich-structured catalyst that enables controlled growth of Li2O2 spatially and structurally [226]. It is found that thin-layer Li2O2 (below 10 nm) can grow conformally on the surface of Au nanoparticles confined between graphene and Au. This unique crystalline behavior of Li2O2 effectively relieves or defers the electrode deactivation with Li2O2 accumulation and largely reduces the contact of Li2O2 with graphene and electrode. Apart from these typical precious metals, a great deal of research has been made on Ni, Cu, Co, Zn, etc. metal design, which also display strong catalytic activity for OER or ORR processes [227,228]. For example, Zhang and co-workers prepared a catalyst of Ni nanoparticles uniformly dispersed onto N-doped graphene through hydrothermal method [229]. They used first-principles computation technique to decipher the catalytic function of Ni centres, and results reveal desirable adsorption capability for both Li (−0.99 eV for Li/Ni (111) and −1.19 eV for Li/Ni (200)) and CO2 (−0.36 eV for CO2/Ni (111) and −0.54 eV for CO2/Ni (200)) (Fig. 11c). It suggests that Ni nanoparticles are excellent active sites for the reaction of Li and CO2. Later, they reported another metal catalyst consisting of Cu nanoparticles dispersed onto N-doped graphene by a gel-like film synthesis approach [230]. As verified, Cu nanoparticles with highly catalytic activity can accelerate the reaction between Li2CO3 and carbon during charging process. It is speculated that superoxide radicals generated from the self-decomposition of Li2CO3 unavoidably corrode electrodes during the charge process. Nevertheless, on the surface of Cu nanoparticles, CuO with 3–5 nm thin layer is formed accordingly thus to stabilize cathode during following cycles, as shown in Fig. 11(d). In addition, Xie et al. reported a 3D porous fractal Zn cathode employed in Li-CO2 battery and firstly found a novel fuel-gas CO generated during discharge process, based on the reaction 2 Li + + 2 CO 2 + 2 e - → CO + Li 2 CO 3 [231]. Nam and co-workers prepared a CuFe alloy coated with a graphitic carbon shell and used it as highly durable electrocatalyst toward metal air battery [232]. Theoretical models and experimental results demonstrate that the CuFe alloy has a more moderate binding strength for oxygen molecules as well as the final product, OH−, thus facilitating the oxygen reduction process (Fig. 11e). Such theoretical models to measure binding energy toward polysulfides are also applied in sulfur battery, in order to enhance polysulfides anchoring and conversion issues. The typical catalysts with moderate binding energy [233–246] are exhibited in Table 1 . Usually, particle or cluster architecture is simpler to manufacture than single atom catalysts, so we can use facile synthesis way to realize a uniformly distributed metal catalyst. Besides, compared with single atom catalysts, metal catalysts can maintain good stability over a wide range of temperature and pressure, and thus function for a prolonged time in redox reaction. However, they are vulnerable to chemical interference during reaction, which could possibly result in deactivation. Irreversible poisoning can easily happen when metal catalysts come into contact with oxides or sulfides. 3.1.8 Others (NB, NC, P, etc.) Apart from above-mentioned catalysts, other types, such as graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), boron nitride (BN), and phosphorous (P), are also intensively applied in diverse batteries. Phosphorene, one typical 2D layered material, offers a direct band gap between the zero gap of graphene and large band gap from 2D transitional metal dichalcogenides, showing great potential toward energy storage application. Each phosphorus atom bonds with three neighboring atoms forming a puckered honeycomb structure. The g-C3N4 with 2D graphene-resembling structure is made up of tri-s-triazine networks joined by planar amino groups, which claims stronger affinity for sulfur/sulfides species owing to the large concentration of chemically polar pyridinic-N sites. BN nanosheets isoelectronic with graphene embrace many remarkable properties such as high resistance to oxidation and good chemical inertness. In conclusion, heterogeneous catalysts are usually in different phase states from the reactants, promoting the reaction by forming catalytic interfaces. Owing to limited contact area between catalysts and reactants, it is required for the heterogeneous catalysts to possess large specific surface area and as many active sites as possible to ensure good catalytic performance. However, heterogeneous catalysts are usually in a solid state, so they can be easily recovered and reused. 3.2 Homogeneous catalysts In alkali metal battery, soluble catalysts are sometimes introduced to specifically target the soluble intermediates that are formed during redox reaction [247–251]. For example, Bergner et al. introduced 10 mM 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidinyloxyl (TEMPO) into electrolyte and meanwhile investigated catalytic mechanism toward Li-O2 battery (Fig. 12 a) [252]. They observed that the introduction of mobile TEMPO+ into the electrolyte allows for fast oxidation of large Li2O2 particles with low electrical conductivity, as well as Li2O2 formed onto separator. Consequently, the battery demonstrates a decreased charging voltage, improved cycle stability, and higher round-trip efficiency. Then, Kundu and co-workers employed tris[4-(diethylamino)phenyl]amine (TDPA) as redox mediator to enhance rechargeability of Li-O2 battery [253]. The suitability of TDPA is confirmed by two couples’ redox potentials at lower voltage in cell along with high electrochemical stability, verifying fast diffusion kinetics (Fig. 12b). Later, Ryu et al. found that the heme molecule can serve as mobile redox catalyst and oxygen shuttle to accelerate the OER in non-aqueous Li-O2 battery [254]. Throughout discharge progress, heme (Fe3+) transforms into heme (Fe2+) or the heme (Fe2+)–O2, as described by the following reactions. Heme Fe 3 + + e - → Heme Fe 2 + Heme Fe 3 + + O 2 - → Heme Fe 2 + - O 2 On charging, heme (Fe2+)–O2 and heme (Fe2+) convert into heme (Fe3+), while releasing oxygen. Simultaneously, heme (Fe3+) has the ability to accept available O2 − ions and reforms heme (Fe2+)–O2 (as shown in Fig. 12c). The reactions can be represented as follows. Heme Fe 2 + - O 2 → Heme Fe 3 + + O 2 + e - Heme ( Fe 3 + ) + O 2 - → Heme ( Fe 2 + ) - O 2 Heme Fe 2 + → Heme Fe 3 + + e - Another typical example is soluble N,N′-bis(salicylidene)ethylenediaminocobalt(II) (CoII-salen), which has been demonstrated to be an efficient additive to modify conversion reaction in Li-O2 battery [255]. The soluble CoII-salen as O2 − carrier could catalyze Li2O2 formation based on the reaction of (CoII-salen)2-O2 2− + 2Li+ + 2e− → 2CoII-salen + Li2O2. Notably, this reaction facilitates the direct formation of Li2O2 without the generation of intermediates that may react with the electrolyte. The potential reaction mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 12(d). The results obtained from linear sweep voltammetry show a significant negative shift of 300 mV in the ORR peak upon the addition of CoII-salen into the electrolyte. Almost at the same time, N-methylphenothiazine (MPT) is verified as another kind of soluble mediator to promote the decomposition of Li2O2 [256]. Chen et al. conducted a comprehensive study to gain deeper insight into the catalytic effect of different soluble catalysts, with emphasis toward kinetics of Li2O2 oxidation [257]. By investigating the apparent rate constants (K app) for the Li2O2 oxidation reaction over these catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 12(e), they discovered that 2-azaadamantane-N-oxyl (AZO) demonstrates the highest K app value among the catalysts studied, leading to remarkable performance with charging current of up to 1.9 A cm−2. It is worth noting that the presence of the mobile catalyst MPT does not significantly affect the discharging potential. However, during the recharge process, MPT+ cations are generated at the surface of the oxygen electrode and subsequently oxidize the solid discharge product Li2O2 through a chemical reaction. Initial discharge/charge curves demonstrate that the addition of MPT into electrolyte results in an obvious reduction of charge potential to approximately 3.63 V and an enhancement of round-trip efficiency to nearly 76%, as depicted in Fig. 12(e). Besides TEMPO, TDPA, heme molecule, CoII-salen, and MPT, iodide also can act as redox mediator to improve the performance of Li-O2 battery. For example, Lee and co-workers added CsI into the electrolyte and studied its effects on Li anode and oxygen electrode [258]. They found that the I− ions can promote the dissolution of Li2O2 thus to realize a reduced overpotential (0.84 V), while Cs+ ions are adsorbed on the surface of Li anode as an electrostatic shield to prevent the growth of Li dendrite (Fig. 12f). In addition, Nakanishi et al. highlight the importance of considering the redox potential for both the I−/I3 − and I3 −/I2 redox couples. In their research, 100 mM LiI in 1.0 M Li[TFSA]/DMSO provides the most effective redox mediation but conversely exhibits the highest degree of redox shuttling (in the absence of O2). Besides, the balance between effective limitation of redox shuttle and ease of mediator diffusion to discharge products is of great importance [259]. To conclude, homogeneous catalysts are soluble and do not precipitate with reactants in a reaction solution. They usually promote the reaction by generating active intermediates, which can continue to react with the reactants to form products. Due to the ability of homogeneous catalysts to interact with reactants, the reaction rate is usually faster, and the reaction rate mainly depends on the concentration of the catalyst and reactant. Due to the solubility of homogeneous catalysts in reaction solutions, the recovery of catalysts is relatively difficult and requires methods such as extraction and distillation. 4 Conclusions and perspectives Alkali metal batteries based on conversion reaction exhibit notable enhancement in discharging-charging capacity. Nevertheless, in terms of practical application, the multi-electron multi-step conversion progress brings about a series of side reactions, resulting in limited conversion efficiency and restricted cycling capacity. To solve this fundamental issue and thus guarantee desirable electrochemical performance, catalysts are introduced to modulate conversion barrier and thus smooth discharge-charge behavior. By far, the emerging catalysts applied in alkaline metal battery can be categorized into the homogenous catalysts and heterogeneous catalysts. Homogeneous catalysts refer to catalysts that are soluble and do not precipitate with reactants in reaction solution. They interact with reactant molecules to promote the reaction progress. In contrast, heterogenous catalysts refer to catalysts that are in different phase states from reactants, and thus they promote the reaction through interfacial surface. Toward the metal battery, due to the existence of the inter-surface of cathode electrode and electrolyte, the heterogenous catalysts are more frequently applied to accelerate the cathode redox reaction. Due to different discharge-charging mechanisms from different metal batteries, the suitable or optimal catalysts could vary. Compared with lithium gas battery, there is a wide range of catalysts which can be applied in lithium sulfur battery, for example, Ti/V/Cr/Mn/Fe/Co/Ni/Cu/Zn based materials. In contrast, owing to the complicated gas-liquid-solid interface, the operation of Li-gas battery suggests more restriction in catalysts design. Thereby, only partial catalysts can be used such as Fe/Ni/Co based composites for Li-O2 battery and Mo/Fe/Ni based materials for Li-CO2 battery. Due to varied reactants, intermediates, and discharging products involved in different battery systems, catalysts are required to deliver modulated interaction toward reactant molecules in specific condition. In most cases, the combination of experimental outcomes and theoretical prediction is utilized to measure which catalyst is optimal. Being a desirable catalyst, it is required to realize low conversion energy barrier, especially in the rate determined step. To be more specific, in Li-S battery, it is under urgent demand that the catalysts introduced could trigger fast redox reaction converting Li2S3/Li2S2 into Li2S, enabling comparably low energy consuming. Regarding nonaqueous Li-O2 battery, the oxidation conversion of Li2O2 with sluggish kinetics should be firstly considered. Overall, catalysts play different roles in different battery systems and usually larger specific surface area along with more exposure of active sites is beneficial for catalytic activity and performance promotion. Although a great deal of catalysts with diverse configurations achieves great success in metal battery, the electrochemical performance is still unsatisfactory for practical application. The study of the structure-activity relationship can help us deepen our understanding on the properties of catalysts, and provide theoretical guidance for the development of efficient and highly selective catalysts. We can establish a study on its structure-activity relationship based on the following aspects: the number and properties of active sites on the catalytic interface, the pore structure and size of the catalysts, corresponding surface charge properties, and so on. Usually, large specific surface area with high conductivity is required, for example, the porous carbon-based materials. Moreover, the number of active sites per unit area is another significant criterion for an optimal catalyst. Usually, the more active sites exposed at the reaction interface, the higher the catalytic efficiency is. More importantly, the catalytic efficiency per active sites, namely, the intrinsic activity, is regarded as priority criterion to be considered while designing an effective catalyst. In future, significant attention should be devoted to understanding the specific catalytic mechanism in diverse catalysts, especially those closely correlated with diverse nano-structures or even electronic distribution. She works as a postdoctoral fellow in Prof. Zijian Zheng’s group from 2021. Her research has been focused on the catalyst materials for energy storage and conversion. Xuan-Wen Gao obtained his Ph.D. degrees from University of Wollongong, Australia. She is now a full-time associate professor working at Northeastern University School of Metallurgy. Her research has been focused on energy conversion and storage materials. Hailong Xu is working at the School of Materials Science and Engineering at Northwestern Polytechnical University. He received his Ph.D. in materials science at Northwestern Polytechnical University at 2019, and he worked as a postdoctoral fellow in Prof. Zijian Zheng’s group between 2020 and 2023. His research has been focused on the functional carbon materials for EMI shielding and flexible battery applications. Yichun Ding obtained his Ph.D. degree from South Dakota School of Mines & Technology, United States. He is now working at Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research has been focusing on developing advanced polymeric and nano materials for flexible electronics and energy applications. Shi-Xue Dou is an outstanding professor at the University of Wollongong in Australia, as founder of the Institute for Superconductivity and Electronic Materials (ISEM) at Wollongong University, and currently a professor at Shanghai Institute of Technology. He mainly engages in basic scientific and applied technological research in areas such as electrochemical energy storage, hydrogen energy and fuel cells, carbon capture, new two-dimensional materials, superconducting materials, etc. Wen-Bin Luo is a full-time professor at Northeastern University (Shenyang, China) and Director of Institute for Energy Electrochemistry and Urban Mines Metallurgy. He is a honored as a National Young Talent and LiaoNing Revitalization Talent. He obtained his Bachelor's and Master's degrees from Northeastern University in 2009 and 2011, respectively, and completed his Ph.D. at the University of Wollongong (Australia) in 2015. His research focuses on energy conversion and storage materials and urban mines metallurgy.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium metal batteries are regarded as prominent contenders to address the pressing needs owing to the high theoretical capacity. Toward the broader implementation, the primary obstacle lies in the intricate multi-electron, multi-step redox reaction associated with sluggish conversion kinetics, subsequently giving rise to a cascade of parasitic issues. In order to smooth reaction kinetics, catalysts are widely introduced to accelerate reaction rate via modulating the energy barrier. Over past decades, a large amount of research has been devoted to the catalyst design and catalytic mechanism exploration, and thus the great progress in electrochemical performance has been realized. Therefore, it is necessary to make a comprehensive review toward key progress in catalyst design and future development pathway. In this review, the basic mechanism of lithium metal batteries is provided along with corresponding advantages and existing challenges detailly described. The main catalysts employed to accelerate cathode reaction with emphasis on their catalytic mechanism are summarized as well. Finally, the rational design and innovative direction toward efficient catalysts are suggested for future application in metal-sulfur/gas battery and beyond. This review is expected to drive and benefit future research on rational catalyst design with multi-parameter synergistic impacts on the activity and stability of next-generation metal battery, thus opening new avenue for sustainable solution to climate change, energy and environmental issues, and the potential industrial economy.
